fields.description:
Tested on Console installed on CentOS from packages

{code}
[root@g-08-09 ~]# rpm -qi eucaconsole
Name        : eucaconsole                  Relocations: (not relocatable)
Version     : 4.0.0                             Vendor: (none)
Release     : 0.1.0.329.20140425gite63fb74a.el6   Build Date: Fri 25 Apr 2014 02:17:03 PM PDT
Install Date: Mon 28 Apr 2014 10:54:10 AM PDT      Build Host: ip-172-26-118-220
Group       : Unspecified                   Source RPM: eucaconsole-4.0.0-0.1.0.329.20140425gite63fb74a.el6.src.rpm
Size        : 6104460                          License: BSD and MIT and OFL
Signature   : RSA/SHA1, Fri 25 Apr 2014 02:17:13 PM PDT, Key ID 48827ef99d7b073c
URL         : http://github.com/eucalyptus/koala
Summary     : Eucalyptus Management Console
Description :
TODO
{code}

Tested with SSL enabled on MAC/FF.

Steps:

1) Installed hvm windows image on the cloud
2) added launch permission for "all"

{code}
[root@g-08-09 ~]# euca-describe-images
IMAGE	emi-153a0813	975225421041/Ubuntu-precise	975225421041	available	public	x86_64	machine				instance-store	hvm	
IMAGE	emi-524153f1	975225421041/Windows_2003_x64	975225421041	available	public	x86_64	machine			windows	instance-store	hvm	
[root@g-08-09 ~]# euca-describe-image-attribute -l emi-524153f1
launchPermission	emi-524153f1	group	all
{code}

On our standard ui-test-acct-** accounts the newly added windows image would not show up for the first ~10 minutes, not even after refresh.

After that the windows image would randomly not show up on various accounts after log in.
fields.summary: Image added to the cloud randomly does not show up on Images Landing Page

comments.body: Adding movie of the test.

CLI operations on images will not empty the cache in the console, since the images cache is only affected by console operations.  As a workaround, you could hit "Save Changes" for any image to empty the images cache.
[~kgill], I just tested the workaround you suggested. Clicking "Save changes" on a previously installed image did not help. I attached the movie of the test (replaced the old movie).

I cleared cache, logged out and in , and I saw the Cirros image on the LP.
After I launched and instance from it, I could not see it however, then it would show up/ not show up  when I navigated between pages. See attached movie.

[~alice], [~dkavanagh]: Hmm, I think the issue may be due to each gunicorn worker using its own memory space.  Going to research how to best handle this.

See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6422440/django1-3-multiple-gunicorn-workers-caching-problems (although that article references a Django deployment, we're experiencing similar issues here).

Potentially fixed in https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/631

[~kyolee]: Do you have cycles to test the memory usage for branch GUI-855?  We'll need to test with gunicorn, so your console.ini settings should be as follows to match the server:main section in console.default.ini

{code}
[server:main]
use = egg:gunicorn#main
host = 0.0.0.0
port = 8888
workers = 8
worker_class = gevent
{code}

To put this in context, the memory cache is per worker, so one potential fix (pushed in PR 631) is to add the PID to the cache key, which increases the memory usage 8x for 8 workers.

The other workarounds are…
1. Disable image cache (not ideal, esp. on the AWS side)
2. Expect that newly-added images may not display for up to an hour after they are registered

Need to balance those options with the increased memory usage since an 8x (or more) increase is fairly significant.
Sure, love these random things! :-)

We should research other server-side caching options such as memcached or redis for 4.1 or later to avoid the per-worker memory cache overhead.

/cc [~decker]
To clarify, PR 631 increases memory usage on the server, not the client.

I've run some tests this morning, watching memory consumption with gunicorn workers. I didn't use the PR631 change. I ran 2 browsers logging in with AWS, navigating to image and selecting "aws marketplace images", which is the largest image set in each region. I would also switch regions while logged in and load this image set. Here are the things I observed:
 - memory increases slowly in all workers. I'll attach an image of the activity monitor for the workers.
 - memory use doesn't seem to drop after a user logs out.
 - an image set from a region previously loaded during the session is re-loaded much more quickly
 - image sets not yet loaded in the current session took some time to appear in the browser (say, 15 seconds).
 - loading an image set in one session didn't affect the load time of the other session
 - loading an image set by a user didn't affect load times for a subsequent session for that user
 - workers accumulate memory at different rates (i.e. they don't all show the same memory usage)

Some conclusions:
 - memory may continue to grow as the server runs which is consistent with what we saw in 3.4, though to a lesser degree. Likely due in large part to a much smaller set of images being loaded.
 - the image cache isn't shared between users or sessions for the same user
 - having more workers would distribute the memory used across more processes, but unsure if this is actually helpful. It may be possible to reclaim memory if workers were periodically replaced since their memory would be reclaimed when the worker is killed and a new one would start at a lower level.

[~dkavanagh]: What leads you to believe that the image cache isn't shared between users or sessions for the same user?  The image cache isn't keyed to a given session or user, but the fact that each worker has its own cache is likely the cause of confusion here.
[~dkavanagh]: Note that the images cache isn't emptied when a user is logged out, but the cache will expire after the one-hour timeout is reached.
Like I mentioned in the observations. observing load times for the larger image set under various conditions. I could take some measurements to make it a little more empirical.
Yes, the cache-per-worker could obscure the real behavior here.
Pull request at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/631

[~kgill], [~dkavanagh]: I retested this with the current build.  When I first logged in as eucalyptus/admin, I saw the images on the images page.  I then hit the green refresh button and the images were gone.  I kept refreshing the page both from the refresh button and from the browser refresh button.  The images would not reappear.  I then waited for a few minutes and then refreshed the browser and the images reappeared.  However, I refreshed it again and the images were gone.
[~alice]: This is no longer an issue since we are only caching AWS Marketplace and Amazon AMI images.  Suggesting we close this as fixed or as not a bug.
The changes to cache only AWS Marketplace and Amazon AMIs was implemented in https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/665 for GUI-921
Have not seen the issue.
